article.paragraph: Catalan(IPAc-enˈkætəlæn;Laurie Bauer, 2007,The Linguistics Students Handbook, Edinburgh; alsoIPAc-enkætəˈlænorIPAc-enˈkætələnEndonymautonym:catalIPA-cakətəˈɫaorIPA-cakataˈɫa) is aRomance languagesRomance languagenamed for its origins inPrincipality of CataloniaCatalonia, in what is northeasternSpainand adjoining parts ofFrance. It is the national and only official language ofAndorra,sfnWheeler2010191and a co-official language of the Spanishautonomous communities of Spainautonomous communitiesofCatalonia, theBalearic Islands, and theValencian Community(where the language is known asValencian languageValencian, and there exist regional standards). It also has semi-official status in the city ofAlgheroon theItalyItalianisland ofSardinia. It is also spoken with no official recognition in parts of the Spanish autonomous communities ofAragon(La Franja) andRegion of MurciaMurcia(Carche), and in the historic French region ofRoussillon/Northern Catalonia, roughly equivalent to theDepartments of FrancedepartmentofPyrnes-Orientales.sfnWheeler20051

According to the Statistical Institute of Catalonia in 2008 the Catalan language is the second most commonly used in Catalonia, afterSpanish languageSpanish,http://www.idescat.cat/dequavi/?TC=444&V0=15&V1=2&VA=2008&x=13&y=12as a native or self-defining language.The Generalitat of Catalunya spends part of its annual budget on the promotion of the use of Catalan in Catalonia and in other territories.Datos lingsticos en Catalua

Catalan evolved fromVulgar Latinaround the easternPyreneesin the 9th century.sfnCosta CarrerasYates20096–7During theLow Middle Agesit saw a golden age as the literary and dominant language of theCrown of Aragon, and was widely used all over theMediterranean.sfnCosta CarrerasYates20096–7sfnWheeler2010190–191The union of Aragon with the other territories ofSpainin 1479 marked the start of the decline of the language.sfnCosta CarrerasYates20096–7sfnWheeler2010190–191In 1659 Spain cededNorthern CataloniatoFrance, and Catalan was banned in both states in the early 18th century.sfnWheeler2010190–19119th-century Spain saw aRenaixenaCatalan literary revival,sfnWheeler2010190–191sfnCosta CarrerasYates20096–7which culminated in the 1913 orthographic standardization, and the officialization of the language during theSecond Spanish Republic(193139). However, theFrancoist SpainFrancoist dictatorship(193975) banned the language again.sfnWheeler2010190–191

Since theSpanish transition to democracy(19751982), Catalan has been recognized as an official language, language of education, and language of mass media, all of which have contributed to its increased prestige.sfnWheeler2003207There is no parallel in Europe of such a large,bilingualismbilingual,Stateless nationnon-statespeech community.sfnWheeler2003207

Catalan dialects are relatively uniform,sfnMoll195847sfnEnciclopèdia Catalana634–635and are mutually intelligible.sfnWheeler20051sfnCosta CarrerasYates20095sfnFeldhausen20105They are divided into two blocks, Eastern and Western, differing mostly in pronunciation.sfnMoll195847sfnEnciclopèdia Catalana634–635The terms "Catalan" and "Valencian languageValencian" (respectively used inCataloniaand theValencian Community) are two different names for the same language.''"Dictamen de l'Acadmia Valenciana de la Llengua sobre els principis i criteris per a la defensa de la denominaci i l'entitat del valenci"''. Report fromAcadmia Valenciana de la Llenguaabout denomination and identity of Valencian.There are two institutions regulating two standard varieties, theInstitut d'Estudis CatalansInstitute of Catalan Studiesin Catalonia and theAcadmia Valenciana de la LlenguaValencian Academy of the Languagein Valencia. The two standards are based on the same orthographical norms and the differences are similar to those between British and American English.

Catalan shares many traits with its neighboringRomance languages.sfnWheeler20051However, despite being mostly situated in theIberian Peninsula, Catalan differs more fromIberian Romance languagesIberian Romance(such asSpanish languageSpanishandPortuguese languagePortuguese) in terms ofvocabulary,pronunciation, and grammar than fromGallo-Romance languagesGallo-Romance(Occitan languageOccitan,French languageFrench,Gallo-Italic languages, etc.).Marc Howard Ross,''Cultural Contestation in Ethnic Conflict'', page 139. Cambridge University Press, 2007.sfnJud1925sfnColón199333–35sfnMoll195847sfnEnciclopèdia Catalana632sfnFeldhausen20104sfnSchlösser200560fThese similarities are most notable with Occitan.sfnEnciclopèdia Catalana632sfnFeldhausen20104sfnSchlösser200560f

Catalan has an inflectional grammar, with twogrammatical gendergenders(masculine, feminine), and twogrammatical numbernumbers(singular, plural). Pronouns are also inflected forgrammatical casecase,animacyCitation neededFebruary 2015andTV distinctionpoliteness, and can be combined in very complex ways. Verbs are split in several paradigms and are inflected forgrammatical personperson,grammatical numbernumber,grammatical tensetense,grammatical aspectaspect,grammatical moodmood, andgrammatical gendergender. In terms of pronunciation, Catalan has many words ending in a wide variety of consonants and some consonant clusters, in contrast with many other Romance languages.sfnEnciclopèdia Catalana630
article.heading: Etymology and pronunciation
article.paragraph: MainEtymology of CataloniaFile:Extensi de la llengua catalana als Pasos Catalans.pngthumbPasos CatalansCatalanThe wordCatalanderives from the territory ofCatalonia, itself of disputed etymology. The main theory suggests thatCatalunya(Latin languageLatinGathia Launia) derives from the nameGothiaorGauthia("Land of the Goths"), since the origins of the Catalan counts, lords and people were found in theMarch of Gothia, whenceGothland>Gothlandia>Gothalania>Cataloniatheoretically derived.sfnGarcía Venero2006sfnBurke1900154

InEnglish languageEnglish, the term referring to a person first appears in the mid 14th century asCatelaner, followed in the 15th century asCatellain(fromFrench languageFrench). It is first attested a language name by 1792. The termCatalonianis first attested in 1707.Catalancan be pronounced asIPAc-enˈkætəlæn,IPAc-enkætəˈlænorIPAc-enˈkætələn.

Theendonymis pronouncedIPA/kə.təˈɫa/in the Eastern Catalan dialects, andIPA/ka.taˈɫa/in the Western dialects. In theValencian Community, the termvalenci(IPA/va.len.siˈa/) is frequently used instead. The names "Catalan" and "Valencian" are two names for the same language.sfnLledó2011334–337See also#About Valencianstatus of Valencianbelow.
article.heading: History

link.part: Fragment of the ''Greuges de Guitard Isarn'' (ca. 10801095), one of the earliest texts written almost completely in Catalan,sfnVeny19979–18sfnMoran200437–38predating the famous ''Homilies d'Organy'' by a century

article.heading: Middle Ages
article.paragraph: furtherOld CatalanPhonological history of CatalanBy the 9th century, Catalan had evolved fromVulgar Latinon both sides of the eastern end of thePyrenees, as well as the territories of the Roman province ofHispania Tarraconensisto the south.sfnCosta CarrerasYates20096–7From the 8th century onwards the Catalan counts extended their territory southwards and westwards at the expense of the Muslims, bringing their language with them.sfnCosta CarrerasYates20096–7This process was given definitive impetus with the separation of theCounty of Barcelonafrom theCarolingian Empirein 988.sfnCosta CarrerasYates20096–7

In the 11th century, documents written inmacaronic languagemacaronic Latinbegin to show Catalan elements,sfnMoran200437–38with texts written almost completely in Romance appearing by 1080.sfnMoran200437–38Old Catalan shared many features withGallo-Romance languagesGallo-Romance, diverging fromOld Occitanbetween the 11th and 14th centuries.sfnRiquer1964

During the 11th and 12th centuries the Catalan rulers expanded up to north of theEbro river,sfnCosta CarrerasYates20096–7and in the 13th century they conquered theKingdom of ValenciaLand of Valenciaand theBalearic Islands.sfnCosta CarrerasYates20096–7The city ofAlgheroinSardiniawas repopulated with Catalan speakers in the 14th century. The language also reachedMurcia, which became Spanish-speaking in the 15th century.sfnWheeler2010190

In theLow Middle Ages, Catalan went through a golden age, reaching a peak of maturity and cultural richness.sfnCosta CarrerasYates20096–7Examples include the work of Majorcan polymathRamon Llull(12321315), the Four Great Chronicles (13th14th centuries), and the Valencian school of poetry culminating inAusis March(13971459).sfnCosta CarrerasYates20096–7By the 15th century, the city ofValenciahad become the sociocultural center of theCrown of Aragon, and Catalan was present all over theMediterraneanworld.sfnCosta CarrerasYates20096–7During this period, the Royal Chancery propagated a highly standardized language.sfnCosta CarrerasYates20096–7Catalan was widely used as an official language in Sicily until the 15th century, and in Sardinia until the 17th.sfnWheeler2010190During this period, the language was what Costa Carreras terms "one of the 'great languages' of medieval Europe".sfnCosta CarrerasYates20096–7

Joanot MartorellMartorell's outstandingsfnCosta CarrerasYates20096–7novel of chivalryTirant lo Blanc(1490) shows a transition from Medieval to Renaissance values, something that can also be seen inBernat MetgeMetge's work.sfnCosta CarrerasYates20096–7The first book produced with movable type in theIberian Peninsulawas printed in Catalan.Trobes en llaors de la Verge Maria("Poems of praise of the Virgin Mary") 1474.sfnCosta CarrerasYates20096–7
article.heading: Start of the modern era
article.paragraph: With the union of the crowns ofKingdom of CastilleCastilleandCrown of AragonAragon(1479), the use ofSpanish languageSpanishgradually became more prestigious.sfnWheeler2010190Starting in the 16th century, Catalan literature experienced a decline, the language came under the influence of Spanish, and the urban and literary classes becamebilingualismbilingual.sfnWheeler2010190
article.heading: French state: 18th to 20th centuries
article.paragraph: File:Interdiction officielle de la langue catalana 2 avril 1700.jpgthumbOfficial Decree Prohibiting the Catalan Language in FranceFile:SpeakFrenchBeClean.jpgthumbright250px"Speak French, be clean", school wall inAyguatbia-Talau, 2010See alsoLanguage policy in FranceVergonhaPatoisWith theTreaty of the Pyrenees(1659),Spainceded theNorthern Catalonianorthern part of CataloniatoFrance, and soon thereafter theNorthern Catalanlocal Catalan varietiescame under the influence ofFrench languageFrench, which in 1700 became the sole official language of the region.sfnWheeler2010191cite webhttp://www.crdp-montpellier.fr/cd66/artscult/fichesVauban/cdvauban/PERIODES/moyenagetempsmodernes/chateaucollioureinterdictioncatalan.pdf''L'interdiction de la langue catalane en Roussillon par Louis XIV''"CRDP, Académie de Montpellier

Shortly after theFrench Revolution(1789), theFrench First Republicprohibited official use of, and enacted discriminating policies against, the nonstandard languages of France (patois), such as Catalan,Alsatian languageAlsatian,Breton languageBreton,Occitan languageOccitan,Flemish, andBasque languageBasque.

Following the French capture ofAlgeria(1833), that region saw several waves of Catalan-speaking settlers. People from the SpanishAlacantprovince settled aroundOran, whereasAlgiersreceived immigration fromNorthern CataloniaandMinorca. Their speech was known aspatuet. By 1911, the number of Catalan speakers was around 100,000. After the declaration of independence of Algeria in 1962, almost all the Catalan speakers fled to Northern Catalonia (asPieds-Noirs) or Alacant.sfnMarfany2002

Nowadays, France only recognizes French as an official language. Nevertheless, on 10 December 2007, theGeneral Council of the Pyrnes-Orientalesofficially recognized Catalan as one of the languages of the departmentcite webhttp://www.cg66.fr/202-charte-en-faveur-du-catalan.htm''Charte en faveur du Catalan''cite webhttp://www.cg66.fr/199-la-catalanitat-a-catalunya-nord.htm''La catalanitat a la Catalunya Nord''and seeks to further promote it in public life and education.
article.heading: Spanish state: 18th to 20th centuries

template.arg: Language politics in Spain under Franco

article.paragraph: The decline of Catalan continued in the 16th and 17th centuries. The Catalan defeat in theWar of Spanish Succession(1714) initiated a series ofNueva planta decreesmeasuresimposing the use ofSpanish languageSpanishin legal documentation.

In parallel, however, the 19th century saw a Catalan literary revival (Renaixena), which has continued up to the present day.sfnWheeler2010191This period starts withBonaventura Carles AribauAribau'sOde to the Homeland(1833); followed in the second half of the 19th century, and the early 20th by the work ofJacint VerdaguerVerdaguer(poetry),Narcs OllerOller(realist novel), andngel GuimerGuimer(drama).sfnCosta Carreras200710–11
In the 19th century, the region ofCarche, in theprovince of Murciawas repopulated with Catalan speakers from theLand of Valencia.sfnWheeler20051
TheSecond Spanish Republic(19311939) saw a brief period of tolerance, with most restrictions against Catalan being lifted.sfnWheeler2010191
article.heading: Present day
article.paragraph: Since theSpanish transition to democracy(19751982), Catalan has been institutionalizated as an official language, language of education, and language of mass media; all of which have contributed to its increased prestige.sfnWheeler2003207InCatalonia, there is no parallel of a large,bilingualismbilingual,European,Stateless nationnon-statespeech community.sfnWheeler2003207The teaching of Catalan is mandatory in all schools,sfnWheeler2010191but it is possible to use Spanish for studying in the public education system of Catalonia in two situations, if the teacher assigned to a class chooses to use Spanish, or during the learning process of one or some recently arrived students.cite webhttp://www.abc.es/sociedad/20130909/abci-cataluna-ordena-incumplir-sentencias-201309081829.htmlCataluña ordena incumplir las sentencias sobre el castellano en las escuelas10 September 2013SpanishCatalonia orders violate the judgments on the Castilian in schoolsThere is also some intergenerational shift towards Catalan.sfnWheeler2010191

InAndorra, Catalan has always been the sole official language.sfnWheeler2010191Since the promulgation of theConstitution of Andorra1993 constitution, several Andorranization policies have been enforced, like Catalan medium education.sfnWheeler2010191

On the other hand, there are severallanguage shiftprocesses currently taking place. InNorthern Catalonia, Catalan has followed the same trend as the other minority languages ofFrance, with most of its native speakers being 60 or older (as of 2004).sfnWheeler2010191Catalan is studied as a foreign language by 30% of the primary education students, and by 15% of the secondary.sfnWheeler2010191The cultural associationLa Bressolapromotes a network of community-run schools engaged in Catalan language immersion programs.

In theAlicante provinceCatalan is being replaced bySpanish languageSpanish, and inAlgherobyItalian languageItalian.sfnWheeler2003207There are also well ingraineddiglossiadiglossicattitudes against Catalan in theValencian Community,Ibiza, and to a lesser extent, in the rest of theBalearic islands.sfnWheeler2010191
article.heading: Classification and relationship with other Romance languages
article.paragraph: File:Romance-lg-classification-en.pngthumb326x326pxChart of Romance languages based on structural and comparative criteria (not on socio-functional ones). Koryakov (2001) includes Catalan inOccitano-Romance, distinct fromIbero-Romance.sfnKoryakov2001The ascription of Catalan to theOccitano-Romance languagesOccitano-Romancebranch ofGallo-Romance languagesis not shared by all linguists and philologists, particularly among Spanish ones, such asRamn Menndez Pidal.
According toPierre BecPire Bc, its specific classification is as follows:

list.listitem: Gallo-Romance languages(alternatively classified asIbero-Romance languagesIbero-Romance language)Occitano-Romance languages(alternatively classified asIberian Romance languages#Family treeEast Iberian language)Catalan language

article.paragraph: Catalan bears varying degrees of similarity to the linguistic varieties subsumed under the cover termOccitan language(see alsoOccitan#Differences between Occitan and Catalandifferences between Occitan and CatalanandGallo-Romance languages). Thus, as it should be expected from closely related languages, Catalan today shares many traits with other Romance languages.
article.heading: Relationship with other Romance languages
article.paragraph: Catalan shares many traits with the other neighboringRomance languages(Italian languageItalian,Sardinian languageSardinian, Occitan, and Spanish).sfnWheeler20051However, despite being mostly situated in theIberian Peninsula, Catalan has marked differences with theIbero-Romancegroup (Spanish languageSpanishandPortuguese languagePortuguese) in terms ofpronunciation, grammar, and especially vocabulary; showing instead its closest affinity withOccitan languageOccitansfnEnciclopèdia Catalana632sfnFeldhausen20104sfnSchlösser200560fand to a lesser extentGallo-Romance(French languageFrench,Franco-Provenal languageFranco-Provenal,Gallo-Italian languagesGallo-Italian).sfnJud1925sfnColón199333–35sfnMoll195847sfnEnciclopèdia Catalana632sfnFeldhausen20104sfnSchlösser200560f

According toEthnologue, the lexical similarity between Catalan and other Romance languages is: 87% with Italian; 85% with Portuguese; 80% with Spanish; 76% withLadin languageLadin; 75% with Sardinian; and 73% with Romanian.

There is evidence that, at least from thesmallcapsa.d.2nd century, the vocabulary and phonology of RomanTarraconensiswas different from the rest of Roman Hispania.sfnEnciclopèdia Catalana632Differentiation has arisen generally because Spanish,Asturian languageAsturian, and Galician-Portuguese share certain peripheral archaisms (Spanishhervir, Asturian/Portuguesefervervs. Catalanbullir, Occitanbolir"to boil") and innovatory regionalisms (Spnovillo, Astnuvielluvs. Cattorell, Octaurl"bullock"), while Catalan has a shared history with the Western Romance innovative core, especially Occitan.sfnColón199355sfnEnciclopèdia Catalana632

TheGermanic languagesGermanicsuperstrate has had different outcomes in Spanish and Catalan. For example, Catalanwiktcafang"mud" andwiktcarostir"to roast", of Germanic origin, contrast with Spanishwikteslodoandwiktesasar, of Latin origin; whereas Catalanwiktcafilosa"spinning wheel" andwiktcapols"temple", of Latin origin, contrast with Spanishwiktesruecaandwiktessien, of Germanic origin.sfnEnciclopèdia Catalana632

The same happens withArabic languageArabicloanwords. Thus, Catalanalfbia"large earthenware jar" andrajola"tile", of Arabic origin, contrast with Spanishtinajaandteja, of Latin origin; whereas Catalanoli"oil" andoliva"olive", of Latin origin, contrast with Spanishaceiteandaceituna.sfnEnciclopèdia Catalana632However, the Arabic element in Spanish is generally much more prevalent.sfnEnciclopèdia Catalana632

Situated between two large linguistic blocks (Ibero-Romance and Gallo-Romance), Catalan has many unique lexical choices, such asenyorar"to miss somebody",apaivagar"to calm down somebody", orrebutjar"reject".sfnEnciclopèdia Catalana632

article.heading: Number of speakers
article.paragraph: The number of people known to be fluent in Catalan varies depending on the sources used. A 2004 study did not count the total number of speakers, but estimated a total of 99.5 million by matching the percentage of speakers to the population of each area where Catalan is spoken.cite webhttp://www20.gencat.cat/portal/site/Llengcat/menuitem.b318de7236aed0e7a129d410b0c0e1a0/?vgnextoidSociolinguistic situation in Catalan-speaking areas. Tables. Official data about the sociolinguistic situation in Catalan-speaking areas: Catalonia (2003), Andorra (2004), the Balearic Islands (2004), Aragonese Border (2004), Northern Catalonia (2004), Alghero (2004) and Valencia (2004)[[Generalitat of Catalonia]]7 August 200813 March 2012The web site of theGeneralitat de Catalunyaestimated that as of 2004 there were 9,118,882 speakers of Catalan.cite webhttp://www20.gencat.cat/docs/Llengcat/Documents/Publicacions/Catala%20llengua%20Europa/Arxius/cat_europa_angles_07.pdfCatalan, language of Europe[[Generalitat of Catalonia]]13 March 2012These figures only reflect potential speakers; today it is the native language of only 35.6% of the Catalan population.Poblacin segn lengua habitual. Datos comparados 2003-2008. Catalua. Ao 2008, Encuesta de Usos Lingsticos de la poblacin (2003 y 2008), Instituto de Estadstica de CataluaAccording toEthnologue, Catalan had four million native speakers and five million second-language speakers in 2012.The most important social characteristic of the Catalan language is that all the areas where it is spoken are bilingual in practice: together with the French language in Roussillon, with Italian in Alghero, with Spanish and French in Andorra and with Spanish in the rest of the territories.

article.heading: Phonology

preblock.preline: The Catalan phonology varies depending on the dialect. Notable features include:sfnEnciclopèdia Catalana630

list.listitem: Marked contrast of the vowel pairs / e/ and / o/, like in otherWestern Romancelanguages, exceptSpanish languageSpanish.sfnEnciclopèdia Catalana630
Lack ofnasalizationnasalizedvowels, unlikePortuguese languagePortugueseorFrench languageFrench.sfnEnciclopèdia Catalana630
Lack ofdiphthongizationofLatinshort,, like inGalician languageGalicianand Portuguese, and unlike French, Spanish and Italian.sfnEnciclopèdia Catalana630
Abundance of diphthongs containing /w/, like in Galician and Portuguese.sfnEnciclopèdia Catalana630

article.paragraph: In contrast with other Romance languages, Catalan has manymonosyllabicwords; and those ending in a wide variety consonants and someconsonant clusters.sfnEnciclopèdia Catalana630Also, Catalan hasfinal obstruent devoicing, thus featuring many couplets likeamic"(male friend") vs.amiga("female friend").sfnEnciclopèdia Catalana630

Central Catalanis considered the standard pronunciation of the language.sfnFeldhausen20105The descriptions below are mostly for this variety.Wheeler 2005 takes the same approachFor the differences in pronunciation of the different dialects, see the section#Dialect pronunciation sectionpronunciation of dialectsin this article.
article.heading: Vowels

link.part: The vowel phonemes of Standard Eastern Catalan

article.paragraph: Catalan has inherited the typical vowel system ofVulgar Latin, with seven stressed phonemes:IPA/a ɛ e i ɔ o u/, a common feature inWestern Romance languagesWestern Romance, exceptSpanish languageSpanish.sfnEnciclopèdia Catalana630Balearic dialectBalearichas also instances of stressed //.sfnWheeler200537,53–54Dialects differ in the different degrees ofvowel reduction,sfnWheeler200537and the incidence of the pair / e/.sfnWheeler200538

InCentral Catalan, unstressed vowels reduce to three:IPA/a e ɛ/ >[ə];IPA/o ɔ u/ >[u];IPA/i/remains distinct.sfnWheeler200554The other dialects have different vowel reduction processes (see the section#Dialect pronunciation sectionpronunciation of dialectsin this article).

article.paragraph: The consonant system of Catalan is rather conservative, shared with most modernWestern Romancelanguages.

list.listitem: IPA/l/has adark lvelarizedallophone insyllable codaposition in most dialects.sfnRecasensEspinosa200520However,IPA/l/is velarized irrespective of position in Eastern dialects like MajorcansfnRecasensEspinosa20053and standard Eastern Catalan.

IPA/v/occurs in Balearic,sfnCarbonellLlisterri199253Alguerese,Valencianstandard Valencianand some areas in southern Catalonia.sfnVeny200751It hasbetacismmergedwithIPA/b/elsewhere.cite bookWheelerMax W.2005The Phonology Of CatalanOxfordOxford University Press13978-0-19-925814-7
Voiced obstruents undergofinal-obstruent devoicing:IPA/b/ >[p], /d/ >[t], /ɡ/ >[k].sfnLloret2003278

Voiced stops becomelenitionlenitedto approximants in syllable onsets, after continuants:IPA/b/ >{{IPAblink|β}}, /d/ >{{IPAblink|ð}}, /ɡ/ >{{IPAblink|ɣ}}.cite bookWheelerMax W.2005The Phonology Of CatalanOxfordOxford University Press10978-0-19-925814-7Exceptions includeIPA/d/afterlateral consonants, andIPA/b/afterIPA/f/. In coda position, these sounds are realized as stops,cite bookHualdeJosé1992Catalan368Routledge978-0-415-05498-0except in some Valencian dialects where they are lenited.sfnRecasensEspinosa20051

There is some confusion in the literature about the precise phonetic characteristics ofIPA/ʃ/,IPA/ʒ/,IPA/tʃ/,IPA/dʒ/. Some sourcescitationCarbonellJoan F.LlisterriJoaquim1992CatalanJournal of the International Phonetic Association221–25310.1017/S0025100300004618describe them as "postalveolar". Otherscite journalRecasensDanielFontdevilaJordiPallarèsMaria Dolors1995Velarization Degree and Coarticulatory Resistance for /l/ in Catalan and GermanJournal of Phonetics23128810.1016/S0095-4470(95)80031-Xcite journalRecasensDanielEspinosaAina2007An Electropalatographic and Acoustic Study of Affricates and Fricatives in Two Catalan DialectsJournal of the International Phonetic Association37214510.1017/S0025100306002829as "back alveolo-palatal", implying that the charactersangle bracket{{IPA|ɕ ʑ tɕ dʑ}}would be more accurate. However, in all literature only the characters forpalato-alveolar consonantpalato-alveolaraffricates and fricatives are used, even when the same sources useangle bracket{{IPA|ɕ ʑ}}for other languages like Polish and Chinese.citationRecasensDaniel1993Fonètica i FonologiaEnciclopèdia Catalana. Here Recasens labels these Catalan sounds as "laminoalveolars palatalitzades"cite bookRecasensDanielPallarèsMaria Dolors2001De la fonètica a la fonologia: les consonants i assimilacions consonàntiques del catalàEditorial ArielBarcelona978-84-344-2884-3. Here the authors label these Catalan sounds as "laminal postalveolar"sfnRecasensEspinosa2007145

The distribution of the two rhoticsIPA/r/andIPA/ɾ/closely parallelsSpanish phonology#Alternationsthat of Spanish. Between vowels, the two contrast, but they are otherwise in complementary distribution: in the onset,IPAblinkrappears unless preceded by a consonant. Dialects vary in regards to rhotics in the coda with Western Catalan generally featuringIPAblinkɾand Central Catalan dialects featuring a weakly trilledIPAblinkrunless it precedes a vowel-initial word in the sameprosodic unit, in which caseIPAblinkɾappears.sfnPadgett20032

In careful speech,IPA/n/,IPA/m/,IPA/l/may begeminationgeminated. GeminatedIPA/ʎ/may also occur.Some analyze intervocalicIPA[r]as the result of gemination of a single rhotic phoneme.Wheeler, Max W. article.heading: Phonological evolution
Dialects
Overview
article.paragraph: File:Catalandialects.pngthumbright300pxMain dialects of CatalansfnFeldhausen20106sfnWheeler20052sfnCosta Carreras20094The dialects of the Catalan language feature a relative uniformity, especially when compared to other Romance languages;sfnMoll195847both in terms ofvocabulary,semantics,syntax,Morphology (linguistics)morphology, andphonology.sfnEnciclopèdia Catalana634–635Mutual intelligibility between dialects is very high,sfnWheeler20051sfnCosta CarrerasYates20095sfnFeldhausen20105estimates ranging from 90% to 95%.The only exception is the isolated idiosyncratic Alguerese dialect.sfnMoll195847

Catalan is split in two major dialectal blocks: Eastern Catalan, and Western Catalan.sfnFeldhausen20105sfnEnciclopèdia Catalana634–635The main difference lies in the treatment of unstressedaande; which have merged to // in Eastern dialects, but which remain distinct as /a/ and /e/ in Western dialects.sfnMoll195847sfnFeldhausen20105There are a few other differences in pronunciation, verbal morphology, and vocabulary.sfnWheeler20051

Western Catalan comprises the two dialects ofNorthwestern CatalanandValencian; the Eastern block comprises four dialects:Central Catalan,Balearic dialectBalearic,Northern CatalanRossellonese, andAlgherese dialectAlguerese.sfnFeldhausen20105Each dialect can be further subdivided in several subdialects.

Central Catalan is considered the standard pronunciation of the language and has the highest number of speakers.sfnFeldhausen20105It is spoken in the densely populated regions of theBarcelona Province (Spain)Barcelona province, the eastern half of the province of Tarragona, and most of the province of Girona.sfnFeldhausen20105

Vowels
article.paragraph: Catalan has inherited the typical vowel system ofVulgar Latin, with seven stressed phonemes:IPA/a ɛ e i ɔ o u/, a common feature inWestern Romance languagesWestern Romance, exceptSpanish languageSpanish.sfnEnciclopèdia Catalana630Balearic dialectBalearichas also instances of stressed //.sfnWheeler200537,53–54Dialects differ in the different degrees ofvowel reduction,sfnWheeler200537and the incidence of the pair / e/.sfnWheeler200538

InEastern Catalan(except Majorcan), unstressed vowels reduce to three:IPA/a e ɛ/ >[ə];IPA/o ɔ u/ >[u];IPA/i/remains distinct.sfnWheeler200554There are a few instances of unreduced [e], [o] in some words.sfnWheeler200554Algueresehas lowered [] to [a].

In Majorcan, unstressed vowels reduce to four:IPA/a e ɛ/follow the Eastern Catalan reduction pattern; howeverIPA/o ɔ/reduce toIPA[o], withIPA/u/remaining distinct, as in Western Catalan.sfnWheeler200553–54

InWestern Catalan, unstressed vowels reduce to five:IPA/e ɛ/ >[e];IPA/o ɔ/ >[o];IPA/a u i/remain distinct.sfnWheeler200553cite bookCarbonellJoan F.LlisterriJoaquim1999CatalanHandbook of the International Phonetic Association: A Guide to the Usage of the International Phonetic AlphabetCambridgeCambridge University Press54–55978-0-521-63751-0This reduction pattern, inherited fromProto-Romance, is also found inItalian languageItalianandPortuguese languagePortuguese.sfnWheeler200553Some Western dialects present further reduction or vowel harmony in some cases.sfnWheeler200553sfnRecasens199675–76,128–129

Central, Western, and Balearic differ in the lexical incidence of stressed /e/ and //.sfnWheeler200538Usually, words with // in Central Catalan correspond to // in Balearic and /e/ in Western Catalan.sfnWheeler200538Words with /e/ in Balearic almost always have /e/ in Central and Western Catalan as well.vagueApril 2014sfnWheeler200538As a result, Central Catalan has a much higher incidence of /e/.sfnWheeler200538

article.paragraph: Standard Catalan, virtually accepted by all speakers,sfnWheeler2003207is mostly based on Eastern Catalan,sfnFeldhausen20105sfnWheeler2003170which is the most widely used dialect. Nevertheless, the standards of Valencia and the Balearics admit alternative forms, mostly traditional ones, which are not current in eastern Catalonia.sfnWheeler2003170

The most notable difference between both standards is some tonicangle bracketeaccentuation, for instance:francs, angls(IEC)francs, angls(AVL). Nevertheless, AVL's standard keeps the grave accentangle bracketè, without pronouncing thisangle bracketeasIPA/ɛ/, in some words like:qu('what'), orValncia. Other divergences include the use ofangle brackettl(AVL) in some words instead ofangle brackettlllike inametla/ametlla('almond'),espatla/espatlla('back'), the use of elided demonstratives (este'this',eixe'that') in the same level as reinforced ones (aquest, aqueix) or the use of many verbal forms common in Valencian, and some of these common in the rest of Western Catalan too, like subjunctive mood or inchoative conjugation in -ix- at the same level as -eix- or the priority use of -emorpheme in 1st person singular in present indicative (-arverbs):jo compreinstead ofjo compro('I buy').

In the Balearic Islands, IEC's standard is used but adapted for the Balearic dialect by theUniversity of the Balearic Islands's philological section. In this way, for instance, IEC says it is correct writingcantamas much ascantem('we sing') but the University says that the priority form in the Balearic Islands must be "cantam" in all fields. Another feature of the Balearic standard is the non-ending in the 1st person singular present indicative:jo compr('I buy'),jo tem('I fear'),jo dorm('I sleep').

In Alghero, the IEC has adapted its standard to theAlguereseAlguerese dialect. In this standard one can find, among other features: the definite articleloinstead ofel, special possessive pronouns and determinantsla mia('mine'),lo sou/la sua('his/her'),lo tou/la tua('yours'), and so on, the use of-v-IPA/v/in the imperfect tense in all conjugations:cantava,creixiva,llegiva; the use of many archaic words, usual words in Alguerese:mancoinstead ofmenys('less'),calqui uinstead ofalg('someone'),qual/qualainstead ofquin/quina('which'), and so on; and the adaptation ofweak pronouns in Catalanweak pronouns.

In 2011, theAragonAragonese governmentpassed a decree for the establishment of a new language regulator of Catalan inLa Franja(the so-called Catalan-speaking areas of Aragon). The new entity, designated asAcadmia Aragonesa del Catal, shall allow a facultative education in Catalan and a standardization of the Catalan language inLa Franja.

article.paragraph: Valencian is classified as aWestern CatalanWesterndialect, along with theNorthwestern Catalannorthwesternvarieties spoken in Western Catalonia (provinces ofLleida provinceLleidaand the western half ofTarragona provinceTarragona).sfnFeldhausen20105sfnWheeler20052–3The various forms of Catalan and Valencian are mutually intelligible (ranging from 90% to 95%)Central Catalan has 90% to 95% inherent intelligibility for speakers of Valencian (1989 R. Hall, Jr.), cited inEthnologue.

Linguists, including Valencian scholars, deal with Catalan and Valencian as the same language. The official regulating body of the language of the Valencian Community, theAcadmia Valenciana de la LlenguaValencian Academy of Language(Acadmia Valenciana de la Llengua,AVL) declares the linguistic unity between Valencian and Catalan varieties.''"Dictamen de l'Acadmia Valenciana de la Llengua sobre els principis i criteris per a la defensa de la denominaci i l'entitat del valenci"''. Report fromAcadmia Valenciana de la Llenguaabout denomination and identity of Valencian.

template.arg: [T]he historical patrimonial language of the [[Valencian people]], from a philological standpoint, is the same shared by the autonomous communities of [[Catalonia]] and [[Balearic islands]], and [[Principality of Andorra]]. Additionally, it is the patrimonial historical language of other territories of the ancient [[Crown of Aragon]] [...] The different varieties of these territories constitute a language, that is, a "linguistic system" [...] From this group of varieties, Valencian has the same hierarchy and dignity as any other dialectal modality of that linguistic system [...]

Ruling of the Valencian Language Academy of 9 February 2005, extract of point 1.{{sfn|Acadèmia Valenciana de la Llengua|2005}}Original full text of Dictamen 1: ''D’acord amb les aportacions més solvents de la romanística acumulades des del segle XIX fins a l’actualitat (estudis de gramàtica històrica, de dialectologia, de sintaxi, de lexicografia…), la llengua pròpia i històrica dels valencians, des del punt de vista de la filologia, és també la que compartixen les comunitats autònomes de Catalunya i de les Illes Balears i el Principat d’Andorra. Així mateix és la llengua històrica i pròpia d’altres territoris de l’antiga Corona d’Aragó (la franja oriental aragonesa, la ciutat sarda de l’Alguer i el departament francés dels Pirineus Orientals). Els diferents parlars de tots estos territoris constituïxen una llengua, és a dir, un mateix «sistema lingüístic», segons la terminologia del primer estructuralisme (annex 1) represa en el Dictamen del Consell Valencià de Cultura, que figura com a preàmbul de la Llei de Creació de l’AVL. Dins d’eixe conjunt de parlars, el valencià té la mateixa jerarquia i dignitat que qualsevol altra modalitat territorial del sistema lingüístic, i presenta unes característiques pròpies que l’AVL preservarà i potenciarà d’acord amb la tradició lexicogràfica i literària pròpia, la realitat lingüística valenciana i la normativització consolidada a partir de les Normes de Castelló.''

article.paragraph: The AVL, created by the Valencian parliament, is in charge of dictating the official rules governing the use of Valencian, and its standard is based on the Norms of Castell (Normes de Castell). Currently, everyone who writes in Valencian uses this standard, except the Royal Academy of Valencian Culture (Acadmia de Cultura Valenciana, RACV), which uses for Valencian an independent standard.

Despite the position of the official organizations, an opinion poll carried out between 2001 and 2004Casi el 65% de los valencianos opina que su lengua es distinta al cataln, segn una encuesta del CISshowed that the majority of the Valencian people consider Valencian different from Catalan. This position is promoted by people who do not use Valencian regularly.sfnWheeler2003207Furthermore, the data indicates that younger generations educated in Valencian are much less likely to hold these views. A minority of Valencian scholars active in fields other than linguistics defends the position of the Royal Academy of Valencian Culture (Acadmia de Cultura Valenciana, RACV), which uses for Valencian a standard independent from Catalan.List of RACV academics

This clash of opinions has sparked much controversy. For example, during the drafting of theEuropean Constitutionin 2004, the Spanish government supplied theEuropean UnionEUwith translations of the text intoBasque languageBasque,Galician languageGalician, Catalan, and Valencian, but the latter two were identical.Isabel I Vilar, Ferran.''"Traducci nica de la Constituci europea"''. I-Zefir. 30 Oct 2004. 29 Apr 2009.
article.heading: Vocabulary
Word choices
article.paragraph: Despite its relative lexical unity, the two dialectal blocks of Catalan (Eastern and Western) show some differences in word choices.sfnEnciclopèdia Catalana632Any lexical divergence within any of the two groups can be explained as an archaism. Also, usuallyCentral Catalanacts as an innovative element.sfnEnciclopèdia Catalana632

Literary Catalan allows the use of words from different dialects, except those of very restricted use.sfnEnciclopèdia Catalana632However, from the 19th century onwards, there is a tendency of favoring words of Northern dialects in detriment of others, even though nowadays there is a greater freedom of choice.sfnEnciclopèdia Catalana632
article.heading: Latin and Greek learned words
article.paragraph: Like other languages, Catalan has a large list of learned words from Greek and Latin. This process started very early, and one can find such examples inRamon Llull's work.sfnEnciclopèdia Catalana632On the fourteenth and fifteenth centuries Catalan had a number of Greco-Latin learned words much superior to other Romance languages, as it can be attested for example inRos de Corella's writings.sfnEnciclopèdia Catalana632
article.heading: Word formation
article.paragraph: The process ofmorphological derivationin Catalan follows the same principles as the otherRomance languages,sfnEnciclopèdia Catalana631whereagglutinationis common. Many times, several affixes are appended to a preexisting lexeme, and some sound alternations can occur, for exampleelctric['lktrik] ("electrical") vs.electricitat[lktrisi'tat].Prefixesare usually appended to verbs, for as in''preveure'' ("foresee").sfnEnciclopèdia Catalana631
There is greater regularity in the process ofword-compounding, where one can find compounded words as much as in English.sfnEnciclopèdia Catalana631

Nouns,adjectives,pronouns, andarticle (grammar)articlesareinflectioninflectedforgrammatical gendergender(masculine and feminine), andgrammatical numbernumber(singular and plural). There is nocase (grammar)caseinflexion, except in pronouns.sfnSwan200197–98
Verbsare highly inflected forperson (grammar)person,number (grammar)number,tense (grammar)tense,aspect (grammar)aspect, andmood (grammar)mood(including asubjunctive moodsubjunctive).sfnSwan200197–98

article.paragraph: Ingender inflection, the most notable feature is (compared toPortuguese languagePortuguese,Spanish languageSpanishorItalian languageItalian), the loss of the typicalmasculinesuffix-o. Thus, the alternance of-o/-a, has been replaced by/-a.sfnEnciclopèdia Catalana630There are only a few exceptions, likeminso/minsa("scarce").sfnEnciclopèdia Catalana630Many not completely predictable morphological alternations may occur, such as:sfnEnciclopèdia Catalana630

list.listitem: Affrication:boig/boja("insane") vs.lleig/lletja("ugly")
Loss ofn:pla/plana("flat") vs.segon/segona("second")
Final obstruent devoicing:sentit/sentida("felt") vs.dit/dita("said")

article.paragraph: Catalan has fewsuppletionsuppletivecouplets, like Italian and Spanish, and unlike French. Thus, Catalan hasnoi/noia("boy"/"girl") andgall/gallina("cock"/"hen"), whereas French hasgaron/filleandcoq/poule.sfnEnciclopèdia Catalana630

There is a tendency to abandon traditionally gender-invariable adjectives in favour of marked ones, something prevalent inOccitanand French. Thus, one can findbullent/bullenta("boiling") in contrast with traditionalbullent/bullent.sfnEnciclopèdia Catalana630

As in the other Western Romance languages, the main plural expression is the suffix-s, which may create morphological alternations similar to the ones found in gender inflection, albeit more rarely.sfnEnciclopèdia Catalana630The most important one is the addition of-o-before certain consonant groups, aphoneticphenomenon that does not affect feminine forms:el pols/els polsos("the pulse"/"the pulses") vs.la pols/les pols("the dust"/"the dusts").sfnEnciclopèdia Catalana630–631

article.paragraph: The inflection of determinatives is complex, specially because of the high number of elisions, but is similar to the neighboring languages.sfnEnciclopèdia Catalana631Catalan has more contractions of preposition + article thanSpanish languageSpanish, likedels("of + the [plural]"), but not as many asItalian languageItalian(which hassul,col,nel, etc.).sfnEnciclopèdia Catalana631

Central Catalan has abandoned almost completely unstressed possessives (mon, etc.) in favour of constructions of article + stressed forms (el meu, etc.), a feature shared with Italian.sfnEnciclopèdia Catalana631
article.heading: Personal pronouns

table.tablecaption: Catalan stressed pronounssfnFabra192642

article.paragraph: MainCatalan personal pronounsThe morphology of Catalan personal pronouns is complex, specially in unstressed forms, which are numerous (13 distinct forms, compared to 11 in Spanish or 9 in Italian).sfnEnciclopèdia Catalana631Features include the gender-neutralhoand the great degree of freedom when combining different unstressed pronouns (65 combinations).sfnEnciclopèdia Catalana631

Catalan pronouns exhibitTV distinction, like all other Romance languages (and most European languages, but not Modern English). This feature implies the use of a different set of second person pronouns for formality.

This flexibility allows Catalan to useextrapositionextensively, much more than French or Spanish. Thus, Catalan can havem'hi recomanaren("they recommended me to him"), whereas in French one must sayils m'ont recommand lui, and Spanishme recomendaron a l.sfnEnciclopèdia Catalana631This allows the placement of almost any nominal term as a sentenceTopiccommenttopic, without having to use so often thepassive voice(as in French orEnglish languageEnglish), or identifying thedirect objectwith apreposition(as in Spanish).sfnEnciclopèdia Catalana631clear
article.heading: Verbs

tablecaption.bold: Simple forms of a regular verb of the first conjugation:portar("to bring")

article.paragraph: Like all the Romance languages, Catalan verbal inflection is more complex than the nominal.Suffixationis omnipresent, whereas morphological alternations play a secondary role.sfnEnciclopèdia Catalana631Vowel alternances are active, as well as infixation and suppletion. However, these are not as productive as in Spanish, and are mostly restricted to irregular verbs.sfnEnciclopèdia Catalana631

The Catalan verbal system is basically common to all Western Romance, except that most dialects have replaced the synthetic indicative perfect with a periphrastic form ofanar("to go") + infinitive.sfnEnciclopèdia Catalana631

Catalan verbs are traditionally divided into three conjugations, with vowel themes-a-,-e-,-i-, the last two being split into two subtypes. However, this division is mostly theoretical.sfnEnciclopèdia Catalana631Only the first conjugation is nowadays productive (with about 3500 common verbs), whereas the third (the subtype ofservir, with about 700 common verbs) is semiproductive. The verbs of the second conjugation are fewer than 100, and it is not possible to create new ones, except by compounding.sfnEnciclopèdia Catalana631clear
article.heading: Syntax
article.paragraph: The grammar of Catalan follows the general pattern of Western Romance languages. The primaryword orderisSubjectverbobjectSVO(subjectverbobject).The World Atlas of Language Structures. wals.info.
article.heading: Catalan names
article.paragraph: InSpain, every person officially has two surnames, one of which is the father's first surname and the other is the mother's first surname.sfnWheeler20058The law contemplates the possibility of joining both surnames with the Catalan conjunctioni("and").sfnWheeler20058article 19.1 of Law 1/1998 stipulates that "the citizens of Catalonia have the right to use the proper regulation of their Catalan names and surnames and to introduce the conjunction between surnames"
